column1: 1978.3."Great music
column2: horrible mastering Wishmaster is one of my favorite Nightwish albums. However
column3: I was always disappointed with the insanely high dynamic range compression and distortion on the CDs. So I thought why not try the LP instead - with any luck it'll have a completely different master. Unfortunately
column4: it seems like all they did was apply the RIAA curve to the CD and cut it into vinyl.If you're buying this for the collector's value then great
column5: but if you actually want to listen to it don't bother and just stick with the CD instead."

column1: 1979.5."The Greatest Band To Ever grace my ears Nightwish Rules! The Music is spine tingling and melodic while powerful. Everything I thought I knew About Music has changed forever. As a long Time fan of Savatage
column2: and other prog-metal bands.. Nightwish has become my favorite. I can play their music over and over... I never thought I would enjoy Opera but her voice seems to be meant for it...like we never should have had to listen to it any other way. The world is full of tasteless crap like eminem
column3: and god please can we forget the boybands and all the other put together mindless gatbage we are smacked with by local radio. NIGHTWISH Thank you for the wonderful barrage of sound you have given to me. I still love my other-prog metal bands but Nightwish has something for everyone who enjoys ""TRUE"" Music. Death to the false ones! LOL"

column1: 1980.5."The perfect formula still to be copied Nightwish works so near perfection! None of the other similar bands (Lacuna Coil
column2: Sinergy
column3: Stratovarius
column4: Angra...) even approach this. No
column5: Therion approaches. Many people tend to compare Nightwish to doom/goth metal bands such as Theatre Of Tragedy
column6: Tristania and Sins Of Thy Beloved. Please
column7: Nightwish is not doom/goth metal
column8: it's clearly high level POWER METAL! Fast versatile guitar riffs
column9: poignant ballads and above all
column10: intense female vocals. Wishmaster's most touching moment is the gentle ""Two For Tragedy""
column11: when Tarja's passionate lament reaches the soul of the listener. Other highlights are the fast ""Wanderlust"" and ""Crownless"". The last song
column12: ""FantasMic""
column13: is divided in three parts and is also very touching. Wishmaster and its predecessor Oceanborn are without a doubt essential albums for any metal listener..."

column1: 1981.3."Predictable
column2: Boring
column3: Stratovarius clown Well...I heard so much about this CD
column4: and i decided to give it a listen. As a power-metal guitarist
column5: i can tell you that the only thing that stands out about this band
column6: is Tarja's vocals. Music sounds like a predictable Yngwie or/and Stratovarius tune. After all
column7: it's not a bad album
column8: even though it'll become a shelf-material after a few spins. But if you are really looking for some good power metal
column9: listen to Sinergy
column10: Stratovarius
column11: Rhapsody or even Armaggedon."

column1: 1986.4."Just like the hospital and doc's clinic I bought 3 other types of thermometers -temporal scan
column2: auxuliary thermometer (but)
column3: oral thermometer
column4: but was getting tired of guessing her temperature. I just decided to purchase this one
column5: the same one used by my hospital and personal doc. So happy to have peace of mind."

column1: 1987.5."Welch Allen Suretemp Plus 690 Thermometer Finally got fed up with all small digital thermometers
column2: none of which seem to be reliable
column3: or require a full 3-4 minutes to be accurate
column4: which is an aggravating long time for the (OB) patient. I LOVE this ""machine""
column5: it is accurate and well worth the expense !"

column1: 1988.3."Good device but yearly probe replacement required As a physician who has used many electronic thermometers
column2: this one is about the best and fastest. It stands up to abuse well as my nurse has dropped it numerous times and it still functions fine. My only complaint(and the reason why I gave 3 stars not 5) is that the probe needs to be replaced regularly. I spoke with an individual in customer support who stated the average probe lasts approximately one year
column3: then needs to be replaced(an error message comes up
column4: rendering the unit unusable). The probe replacement is ~$85. I think that if you spend this amount of money on a thermometer
column5: you should get more than a years use out of it before having to replace expensive parts."

column1: 1989.3."Welch Allyn Suretemp Plus 690 Electronic Thermometer The thermometer is really good once you get it working. I was not very happy that I bought it ""Brand New"" and when I tried to use it
column2: didn't work. I had to ship the Thermometer Probe back
column3: then waited for a week
column4: then tried again and still wasn't working
column5: so I ended having to ship back the Thermometer with all accesories. It took a few weeks to get it back and working.Welch Allyn however
column6: were very good at keeping the guaranty and sending back to me the thermometer after it was fixed."

column1: 1990.5."Great thermometer
column2: long-lasting We do home care for my dad and have to take his rectal temperature every 2 hours when we turn and re-position him. We have had the same Welch-Allyn Sure Temp 690 thermometer for 4 1/2 years now. We just replaced the well and probe a few months ago. The casing finally cracked after all of this time. We have only had to change the batteries twice
column3: too. It is still working perfectly and we would recommend this thermometer to anyone who really needs to take temperatures often. It is so reliable. This one gets 5 stars!!!!!"

column1: 1991.3."For aficionados only If you've not read any Lawrence this is not the book to start with. It fails as a novel because there is no story to speak of
column2: just a string of scenes to initiate discussion of the issues Lawrence wished to explore. Apologists describe it as picaresque
column3: but there is far more unity to most novels that deserve that descriptor. Nonetheless
column4: there are wonderful scenes that fitfully jar this book to life
column5: Lawrence's admirable command of language
column6: and a brooding homoeroticism aching to burst out. Try this book after you've hit the major works (i.e. Women in Love
column7: etc.)."

column1: 1992.4."once put together..it's great!! This tent takes a little work to put together. I don't know what people are talking about when they refer to the wooden poles and getting splinters as the poles on mine are metal. Anyway
column2: once put together it is quite cool! I am 5ft 9"" and I managed to be able to sit in it along with my 4 year old (sitting) and my 5month old baby (lay down) so there is plenty of space. I got mine on sale at a babies r us store
column3: so I don't think I would actually pay (...)for it though. You could by a basic regular tent for that much!"

column1: 1993.1."Broke in less then a month I bought this tent on 6/6/2005 for my 10 month old boy and used it once at the pool the rest of the time it sat in my dining room. I went to bed one night and it was up
column2: but the next morning it was halfway down. When I went to see what was wrong I saw that one of the rods had snapped off in the metal holder and cannot be fixed. This could actually suffocate a baby if noone was in the room or the baby could hurt themselves if they found the broken rod. I was very disappointed because the size is great. I also agree with the other reviews it is hard to put together because the rods are so tight you have to have alot of strenth to get it set up. Please don't buy this we are going to return but it's such a hassle to spend 39.99 plus tax on something and it breaks in less then a month."

column1: 1994.2."BORING... The information was worthwhile
column2: but I found this video to be blah and boring. If you are going to bother to make a documentary at least make it somewhat entertaining! Add some interesting visuals and use a narrator that catches your attention. Read a book on this subject and by-pass this DVD."

column1: 1995.5."A Great Documentary this documentary tells you the relationship of Lewis Carroll and Alice Liddle. and also tells how alice in wonderland was created. this was a very intersting documentary. if you have not seen this movie then i recommend you do"

1996.2."This may be a shortened version of ""Howlin' Wolf Live Gold"" This CD looks to be a 9 track version of the Howlin' Wolf Live Gold CD (Fine Tune 2212-2) which has 14 tracks and appears to be available through Amazon Marketplace (the first nine tracks are in identical order on both CD's). From listening to the samples on Amazon the sound quality of the 9 track CD appears to be the same since as the Fine Tune version. The Fine Tune audio quality is not all that good
column2: may not really be live
column3: but it is the Wolf
column4: after all. Thought fair warning was in order."

column2: Motzart

column1: 1998.3."Looks Like I Backed Into a Square Deal I originally saw this band in Hollywood at The Roxy in 1977. They were virtual unknowns at the time
column2: opening for Dion - of all artists! I owned the 12"" LP
column3: but lost it somewhere in a move. I have been anxiously waiting for the release of this CD.Although Smoke From A Distant Fire is their best known hit (peaked at #9 in 1977)
column4: there are other strong tracks on this CD. Among them
column5: ""In For The Night"" demonstrates the vocal range and songwriting abilities of both Ed Sanford and John Townsend.The lyrics are especially compelling. Most of the songs tell stories (a la Gordon Bok). Whether they be of love lost
column6: love found or one of my favorites -- ""Lawdy Lou""
column7: a story of a friend who loses another to an overdose -- they are presented along with compelling arrangements.This is late 70s pop-jazz
column8: Steely Dan-inspired music at its best. Good lyrics
column9: instrumentation. This is a ""musicians band"" if ever there was one."

column1: 1999.5."The Witches' God by Janet and Stewart Farrar This is a really good book for people that are studying the gods. I truely enjoyed this book. It was very informative."

2000.5."The best book on Pagan Gods All too often the Pagan God is forgotten in favor of the Goddess. This book will bring the balance back to our lives. It gives the history of many well know Gods as well as many not so well known Ones. It also includes rituals in direct relation to the Gods listed. I love this book! It goes well with The Witches' Goddess!"
2001.4."Best PUR CD
column2: but not just the music is important This is definetely the best PUR CD ever
column3: but I've to add that the lyrics of this band are very important and if you don't understand them
column4: you'd like it much less. I don't say anything against the music with that
column5: but the words have at least the same importance."

column1: 2002.5."Beautiful Submission What struck me the most all throughout the reading of ""Beauty and submission"" is the power and bravery behind Maria Pita's prose. She is undoubtedly a wise old soul. Yet
column2: in the same instance
column3: her no-holds-barred honesty about the lifestyle and personal odyssey with her beloved Dom has a youthful innocence that refreshes and renews like rain in the springtime. Love is new
column4: and forever renewed
column5: by each other. Life obstacles faced by most vanilla lovers face are present along with the countless obstacles any alternative lifestyle will bring. Every such mountain is a challenge scaled with intelligent and triumphant results. Missa's enormous heart
column6: and huge capacity to love and submit to her man in the purest sense
column7: will stay with me (and I'm sure all her readers) long after this book is closed. This real life romance makes fictional renditions pale in comparison."

column1: 2003.1."Where was the editor? Technically this was an exercise in tautology
column2: and albeit the author admits that they are events not presented chronologically/linerally
column3: the whole thing came off as a repetitive scrapbook of free associative ramblings. Cultural allusions were off and revealed just a shallow dip into areas of interest; just deep enough to create a character for a sexual fantasy.Every D/s relationship defines it's own perimeters
column4: but this is the most silly top from the bottom (with a side of kink) i've ever read. Any girl who needs to prover her worth and devotion by degrading any and all around her isn't creating a deeper bond of submission
column5: but pathetically wallowing in a misplaced sense of value (with a heaping side of self-image issues)."

column1: 2004.2."Like a train wreck
column2: you want to look away
column3: but you can't. I picked up Beauty & Submission on a whim
column4: after reading the back cover. I have recently begun to read a few BDSM and thought this book would help broaden my knowledge of the submissive aspect. I was disappointed with the outcome.I thought the book held more issues with jealousy and swinging than the day-to-day life of a lifestyle submissive. I also thought that the slave seemed to switch between a dominant/submissive role. There were quite a few references to watersports which were personally not my cup o' tea
column5: as you might say.I did not enjoy all the pages where she ""quoted"" from her other novels. I believe the book would have been half the size if these would have been cut from the copy. It felt like an attempt to sell her other books."

column1: 2005.3."Disregard the earlier reviews of this album. The information provided by both the professional and customer reviewers for this album does not pertain to this specific title. Although I recommend Distant Light instead of this title
column2: this one features the vocals of Allan Clarke in a similar vein and context to two albums that appeared a few years earlier: the aforementioned Distant Light and Romany.Clarke's vocal work here is admirable; the group itself appears to have shed its Top Pop radio persona (although The Air That I Breathe did do well on the charts)
column3: and offer a more mature and thoughtful collection of tunes."

column1: 2006.3."Need More Information This listing does not indicate the bonus tracks that are included. So
column2: I don't know which version of the album this is.The one to get
column3: of course
column4: is the latest version which includes the previously unreleased bonus tract ""Burn Fire Burn.""I wish I knew if this CD has that song."

column1: 2012.3."Ok read I'm a history lover but will read novels and memoirs. There were points in the book were the author lost me. However not much said about the mother. Title is not good for this book."

2013.2."Not complimentary. This book really disappointed me. It seems like a narrative. No real plot just a rambling repetitive narration of a poor island child. I wish I could say I loved it....but felt really let down."
2014.3."difficult When first buying this book I throught it was gonna be about the author's mother. The book is about this girl name Xuela
column2: who's mother died giving birth to her. Xuela father gave her to the woman who washed his clothes
column3: and only visted every now and then. Xuela eventually moved back in with him and his new family only to move again with another family. I throught Xuela was one of the strangest characthers i've ever read about. Her views on things were so strange. The other thing i didn't like about this book
column4: it had no dialouge
column5: which mean a lot of long paragraphs."

column1: 2015.1."Repetitive and monotone I really wanted to like this book based on the title and the cover art. Instead
column2: I found myself not caring about the narrator whatsoever. She repeats the same few thoughts throughout the entire book. She reminds the reader that her mother is dead and that nobody loves her so many times that I stopped caring about her situation. Her repetition and monotone voice stops the narrator from being truly developed as a character that we can connect with. Some parts of her story seem unnecessary and pointless as they don't really lead to anything of interest later on. Her characterization was too direct and left nothing for the reader to consider for themselves. The title is extremely misleading as we learn absolutely nothing about her mother- aside from her death during childbirth. I am unable to find anything positive to describe about this book
column3: sadly."

column1: 2016.1."Disappointing I had hoped to read a colorful story about life in the Caribbean
column2: and was not expecting the story to be happy and uplifting. However
column3: I was disappointed to discover that the most prevalent topics in the book were the character's bodily smells
column4: excretions
column5: and sex life. I was left wondering what these aspects of the book had to do with the character's mother."

column2: but mostly unpleasant read This is the story of an unhappy woman who refuses to see or seek out any joy in her life. The overall feeling of the story is negative and depressing."

column1: 2018.1."Worst book I've ever read This has got to be one of the most depressing books I have ever read. Not depressing in the sense that the tone of the book was depressing (which it was)
column2: but depressing in the sense that it was such poor quality. This was the first book I ""attempted"" to read by the author
column3: since I couldn't waste my time trying to finish it. I am pretty sure I won't be reading any other books by Jamaica Kincade."

column1: 2019.1."Puzzling After all the hype
column2: and comparison to Camus' ""The Stranger""
column3: I suppose my expectations were high for this book. I found ""Autobiography of my Mother"" completely benign. In some parts
column4: pointless. Unlike Camus' protagonist in ""The Stranger""
column5: Xuela's world-view is too fully revealed to be cleverly wrought and too self-perpetuating to cause empathy with the reader. A self-pitying character
column6: Xuela is hard to empathize with because she decries her father and the white ""conquerers"" for exploiting people and destroying the aboriginal population's culture; yet
column7: Xuela also takes advantage of many -- emotionally and psychologically. Therefore
column8: Xuela just comes across as bitter and codependent and the reader is not compelled to sympathize with her situation. I also found nothing sensual about the book -- the author's placement of masturbation description seemed to come out of nowhere and appears simply awkward. Overally
column9: the book does not deliver compared to the hype"

column1: 2020.4."Sad story - hopeless afterlife Losing a mom - never knowing your mom - living your life in anger. Sad. No redemption. It made me sad that some people stay in that state and do not find the only answer which is Jesus Christ. But I know this is true for many who's hearts remain hard who have a big God void in their lives. It was an interesting story....but very hopeless and sad."
2021.3."The Autobiography of My Mother I thought it very wordy and drawn out and very slow reading. I would have liked a little more ooph in it."
2022.2."The autobiography of my mother Did not really get lost in there book....found it boring....and I really wanted to stop reading it! But chose to painstakingly finish it.."
2023.1."The autobiography of my mother It's not a book I'll ever read again. It was very boring. Glad I didn't pay that much. I give it a star."
2024.2."repetitive This book has flowery language and the story line seems to have potential but the book never goes any where. I skimmed much of it
column2: hoping it would develop plot and character
column3: but it really never did. The plot and language were repetitive and didn't hold my attention. It seemed as though the author had a point she was trying hard to get to but it just never happened."

column1: 2025.1."Pseudo-nihilistic garbage. A waste of paper and ink. What's the point here? It was never fully explicated
column2: and the narrator does not inspire enough interest to carry this woefully inadequate plot - and I use that word loosely. Jamaica Kincaid needs to go back to domestic work"

column1: 2026.1."Do I have to give it a star? Even that single star is more than this book is worth. My Engligh professor assigned this book to me during my sophomore year of college (along with Nectar in a Sieve
column2: a far better
column3: though not terrific book)
column4: and what little I remember of it was that it was just awful (and offal). Her writing is repetitive and choppy
column5: perhaps descriptive but disgustingly so. Do we really need to know the ""wetness between [her] legs""
column6: or that she cooked her menstrual fluid into some poor soul's dinner? I couldn't stand the book. If you want quality
column7: read something by Neil Gaiman
column8: or Stephen King (his descriptions of a girl coming of age in Carrie are much better than this book). Drop the book
column9: throw it
column10: burn it
column11: whatever. It's just not worth reading. How many trees did we lose to its production (and
column12: more importantly
column13: how many talented young writers were rejected because this woman was published). It's just a book not worth reading about a story not worth telling."

column1: 2027.1."Don't buy this book Jean Giorno assigned rights to this story to the public domain. Unscrupulous
column2: evil American publishers are acting contrary to the author's intent and prostituting this work by cracking down on English language versions (including online versions)
column3: even new translations from the French. Don't give your money to greed heads who are 180 degrees in conflict with the principles of this book."

column1: 2028.2."disappointing
column2: confusing
column3: not an good intro to snmp This was not a good first book to learn SNMP
column4: the basic definitions are poor
column5: leading to confusion. As an example
column6: the definition of a subtype I found in another text (a subset of the value set for a type) was quite clear
column7: then I checked the Simple definition of subtype and found its was useful to ""refine the semantics"" of a ""data object"" and that ""it may be useful to create a new data type for strings using other repertoires
column8: such as ASCII"". The author also notes that the ""ASN.1 rules for subtyping are long and complex"". (p 34-35). Hello? This book may be useful as a reference after reading other
column9: better written introductions
column10: but avoid it if you are new to SNMP. Also
column11: I recommend that the novice learn ASN.1 first
column12: rather than alsong with SNMP in a combined text. Also
column13: SNMPv2 has yet to catch on
column14: the Simple book focuses primarily on this version
column15: not of much interest if you are working with version 1."

column1: 2029.1."Reading an RFC is more fun and more informative too! The editor and publisher of this book should be ashamed. It is an extended rant by the author that has no business being bound in hard cover. The Pine Mountain Group recommends excerps from this book to get up to speed with SNMP. I wonder who at PMG is friends with the author. This book will teach only members of the ""network management community"" anything. Anyone seeking entry into the network management community will need to find another door. By reading no more than 20 to 40 pages a day I managed to go through the entire book but I am afraid that I did not add anything to my understanding of SNMP that was not already there from studying for my MCSE. This book was a profound disappointment. It is at once dense
column2: superficial
column3: earnest
column4: and sarcastic. The shame of it is that this author could educate profoundly if a good editor enforced some discipline or a co-author came in to help with communicating with those who are not the author's peers."

column1: 2030.1."Not just disappointed
column2: angered. It's hard to believe that this book was released by a major publisher. It is rife with misspellings and grammatical errors. The thin index is almost useless
column3: as a close examination reveals it to be mostly a list of the author's friends and their nicknames."

column1: 2031.2."Horrible for beginners; no comment as a reference I am a developer with 8 years experience but novice to Network programming. A friend suggested this book as a first and default one to start with. I am completely disappointed. It's not a practical

2033.4."A warm farewell to our stranded friends on Tran-ky-ky. Prolific SF writer Alan Dean Foster wraps up the adventures of the stranded Ethan Fortune and Suka September on the ice planet of Tran-ky-ky in a nice little package for fans of the series. Turns out the thawing of the ice at the equator Ethan saw in the second book (Mission to Moulkin) was not natural at all
column2: someone is actually attempting to thaw out the planet. That could mean possible extinction for the Tran
column3: which is unexceptable to Fortune and September. They and their Tran friends head out on the Slanderscree to see that the process is stopped
column4: permanently. A wonderful ending to a wonderful series
column5: highly recommended."

column1: 2034.5."St. Rose of Lima: the First Canonized Saint in the Americas Excellent read

column1: 2035.4."New Toe jaming sounds Shows a sense of creativity with sound effects that reveals the artist's ability to be in touch with todays concerns. Loved the Twist!"
2036.2."poetic but excessive I have not read any of Charlie Smith's other work
column2: so I can't compare this to previous efforts. His writing is poetic
column3: and truly impressive in short bursts. But over the long haul
column4: the poetry interferes with the prose. Words and phrases seem to be chosen more for their sounds and rhythms than for their contributions to plot
column5: and dialogue can be stilted. Imagery is vivid but occasionally self-indulgent. The storyline is interesting at first but eventually grows gaudy and distasteful. The power of Smith's language is his greatest strength
column6: but it is a strength better suited to poetry than novels."

column1: 2041.3."Essence Magazine Review ESSENCE magazine is one of the finest magazines for progressive Black women and occasionally for Black men. I recommend a subscription to my friends

2089.5."Great Music
column2: and A Lot of It
column3: At A Great Price This disc contains Ornette Coleman's pioneering 37-minute 'Free Jazz' PLUS 40 minutes of shorter pieces recorded in the same year. So for a little less money than the American release of 'Free Jazz' you get about twice as much music
column4: and the title track is the final piece
column5: a fitting climax to a great set of music. That said
column6: the jazz on this disc may be more challenging than some listeners would like
column7: but among the extended collective improvisations of the sixties
column8: besides being the first
column9: this one is more immediately accessible
column10: because it SWINGS and it COOKS! And you can tell the musicians are actively listening to each other and responding to each other's work
column11: not just showing off or venting their emotions. So in a nutshell
column12: 'Free Jazz' is less cosmic than Sun Ra's 'Magic City'
column13: less cerebral than Cecil Taylor
column14: and less primal than Coltrane's 'Ascension'
column15: but probably more likely to hook you into an intensely brilliant musical world."

column1: 2090.5."Different isn't always good--sometimes it's better I'm a commercial pilot and flight instructor. I read many aviation related books and magazines. I don't often read books that contain a lot of poetry

column5: both good and bad
column6: in every page. If you are a pilot

column1: 2157.1."Poor support from Plasplugs About four weeks ago

column3: model number: DWW180US-BX.I am using it for a porcelain tile installation. The original blade worked ok for the initial cuts
column4: but I need to replace it for the proper blade type for the tile. I had bought a porcelain tile replacement blade from a blade mfr when I bought the saw. When I got around to replacing the blade

column6: I was told the ""all blades except the standard have been discontinued"".I just bought this saw four weeks ago! I think it is very irresponsible for a manufacturer to behave in this matter.You can be assured that I will avoid any Plasplug product in the future."

column1: 2158.3."Not bad....but don't expect to cut 45 Not bad for a small saw...the 1hp motor cut nicely. The down side to this saw is that the water guard for the blade blocks your view of the cut. I also had to modify the mount for the water guard so that the tile wouldn't catch on the back end. If you want to cut at 45 degrees forgetaboutit....the tool comes with a rip fence but no miter gauge... although it had a miter gauge slot...I had to make my own jig to cut 45 degrees....on the positve side the water tank is pretty self contained and the water guard kept the mess to a minimum...I've rented the bigger saws for larger jobs and ended up cleaning muddy water off the walls. This unit lasted all day with one fill and no spills over the side onto the floor."
2159.4."Master Tiler Wet Saw Review For the cost
column2: this tile saw met my expectations. Following the setup instructions for aligning the fence
column3: the saw performed well cutting tile. While it is difficult to freehand beveled cuts using the tilting table
column4: it worked well when I used spring clamps to attach a guide strip to the back side of the tile that followed the edge of the tilting table. The water reservoir provided a good source of water to the blade
column5: but I found that I had to replenish the supply of water on a regular basis. I bought this saw to be able to diagonally cut 19"" tiles that would not fit in my sliding table tile saw. The quality of this saw is definately much higher than less costly plastic versions. Having used this tool
column6: I would buy it again if I needed a tile saw."

column1: 2198.5."Magic Malamud Malamud does three or four tricks in his fiction well
column2: and here he does each one to utter perfection. And when taken together
column3: this collection of stories almost transcends Malamud's normal limits: the stories are compressed
column4: short
column5: and below the surface
column6: charged with almost unbearable tension. Unlike other collections of stories (or when you read too many Malamud stories) Malamud does not parody himself in the Magic Barrell. Everything is where it is supposed to be
column7: and works like a well oiled machine. It is a shame that (as of writing this) only eight people have reviewed this masterpiece of a short story collection. In Roth's The Ghost Writer
column8: Zuckerman explains that the world's morality has already passed by the E.I. Lonoff's (a character based on Malamud). Seems Roth was correct... and this is true even more today
column9: thirty years after the publication of The Ghost Writer. We no longer live in Malamud's world
column10: and it is a shame."

2208.5."The first excellent book ever written about Heinlein Finally
column2: somebody has written a truly useful book about that most important of American science fiction authors
column3: Robert A. Heinlein. In the past
column4: sloppy criticism and the grinding of personal axes have ruined every single attempt to produce a book discussing Heinlein's works (I have the misfortune of having read them all). Gifford has produced what has to be the groundwork for all future studies of Heinlein: a basic categorization and numbering of every single published and unpublished work in the canon
column5: along with the insiders' story on each entry. Readable from cover to cover
column6: or as a reference work

column1: 2229.4."A new target of cutting wit? Jokes can be both funny and cutting

column4: men too have been the target of commentary but amusing and attacking for centuries. The illustrations are simple black & white drawings of a ""Victorian"" style

column1: 2241.5."Deliberately frustrating

column1: 2244.2."Zzzzzzzzzz..... TESS is one of the more boring works of literature. Yes

column1: 2245.3."Maybe it's just not my style... It seemed to me that Tess of the D'Urbervilles was a bit dull at times

column4: but they are surrounded by lengthy passages describing everything and anything. Nature
column5: being an important aspect of the novel
column6: receives so much attention
column7: and Hardy expounds upon it so meticulously
column8: that it becomes an effort to read through everything. I was disappointed in the very beginning by this style of narration (actually
column9: thinking of Hardy's other novels
column10: it is very much like him)
column11: but by the end
column12: I found it to be absorbing. The character of Tess is very memorable
column13: and awe-inspiring. I recommend this if you have plenty of time to devote to a novel (not looking for a quick read)

column15: you'll find this to be a very good read."

column1: 2249.2."Bit of a Letdown in the End This is part of my attempt to read classics and non-fiction as well as my usual speculative fiction this year. A few people noted that Hardy is a bit of a hard read

column1: 2259.3."Sad classic novel This is a classic novel that is one of the saddest. It involves a very likeable
column2: innocent country girl who is seduced by a cruel employer. She has a child by that union that dies early in infancy. She later meets a man who loves her but upon learning her past rejects her. She then meets up again with the first man
column3: who forces her to be his mistress. The ending is very sad.Through it all Tess maintains her dignity and is a very likeable character. This novel shows the extreme cruelty of legalistic morality that is not tempered by compassion and respect for others
column4: particularly women during this time period.The book is very well written if you like poetic descriptions and vivid imagery. Hardy is a master of both
column5: and of the human drama."

column1: 2278.5."Alec or Angel? False Morality Exposed through one Woman's Innocence ""I became acquainted with Thomas Hardy through another of his classic works
column2: which lent to my curiosity on this one when the audio version was made available to me. It was an experience
column3: to the say the least
column4: hearing how the innocent life of this girl of late 19th century England played out. For no reason other than her own naiveté is she rendered with injustice and prejudicial attitudes of the day - Hardy's denouncement of his own country's false morals. In my view
column5: all males of our current day and age should find this impressive work required reading
column6: and then determine whether they are an Alec D'urberville or an Angel Clare. It seems we all fall into one category or the other."""

column1: 2696.1."These are not the books you grew up with... Many of us remember being on a wait list at school or at our community libraries to borrow these horrifying gems. Yes
column2: the stories themselves were spooky. Seeing some of our local folklore in print just added to the eerieness. The most important contributor to the scare-factor was the incredibly grotesque pieces of art that accompanied each story. This reprint features a new
column3: popular artist; however
column4: the illustrations don't have that same terror-inducing quality as before.For me
column5: I think the reason is that there was a lot of mystery in Gammell's work
column6: while Helquist's just doesn't leave anything to the imagination. In Gammell's work the picture is set up so that it is happening TO YOU. In Helquist's work
column7: the perspective is such that you can see it happening to the characters. Just doesn't do it for me. You can google the images or check blogs to see for yourself."

column1: 2706.2."Warning for customers Any storyteller can tell you that there's little point in telling scary stories without proper atmosphere. Scary stories are told at night around campfires or in darkness lit only by a single flashlight. When reading this book of folktales
column2: you lose the advantage of total darkness and the timing and tone of a storyteller's voice. What made up for the lack were the strange and frightening illustrations of Stephen Gammell. This edition of the book replaces those with far tamer illustrations. Reading it now is akin to telling a scary story while sitting poolside at noon with all your buddies
column3: there's very little impact or involvement for the reader.I hope someday that Harper Collins will bring back the illustrations that truly made these stories scary
column4: but until then I cannot recommend this edition."

column1: 2717.4."History of Fantasy Very much in the tradition of Edgar Rice Burroughs and H. Rider Haggard
column2: Merritt was one of the early avatars of swords & sorcery fantasy novels. He emerged from the pulp magazines of the 50s to write novels which went on to influence a generation after him._Dwellers in the Mirage_ I found to be a very nice combination of all the things that make early fantasy readable. By turns sly and frightening and full of the high-hat adventure that characterizes speculative fiction of this period.Leif Langdon feels as though he never really belonged in the modern world and this feeling is confirmed when he disappears into a separate society hidden by a natural phenomenon. He feels strangely at home with this lost society and discovers the role that he was meant to play in life.Trainspotters may be interested in noting that Merritt went on sometime after this book to co-author a story with Lovecraft. After reading about the Khalk'ru I am certainly curious who was influencing whom."

column1: 2718.2."Average Lost Civilization Fantasy Dwellers in the Mirage (1932) by Abraham Grace Merritt - 222 pages - rating: 5.5/10The writing style is good and all the elements of a great story are present. If the author had simply written about two comrades descending into adventures in a hidden valley it would have been quite a fine tale. Unfortunately the plot was confused by having the main character not really know who he was half the time eventually leading him to abandon his friend completely.The reader endures a frustrating sense of unfocused direction
column2: forever waiting for the plot to fit back together in a way that feels right. Perhaps the author felt that a simple adventure needed a twist of some sort. Well it did feel twisted
column3: but not in a good way.Claus Kellermann2006 April 15Sci_Fi_Researcher@yahoo.com"

column1: 2727.2."very simple interpretation of bellydance I take group bellydance classes and have been to seminars and workshops. This is bellydance but only the very simplest form. If you are sure you want to dance you should shop around spend just a little more money getting a tape from someone/troup that dances a style you are interested in and has a well known face and name. For example Fat Chance Bellydance for American Tribal style or Aisha Ali for African dance or someone well known for Egyptian or Turkish Caberet. If this is a serious investment for you-get a good tape

2739.1."Bill Nichols should not be allowed to write Bill Nichols is full of words and empty of thought. You need a machete to slash through the tangled sentences in this book
column2: and what you'll find beneath are simplistic
column3: flawed ideas that aren't developed but buried under more verbiage. Nichols stitches suffixes and prefixes to ordinary nouns
column4: creating monsters like ""situatedness
column5: ""hyperrationality
column6: ""reconceptualization
column7: ""polyvocality
column8: ""relationality
column9: ""talismanic""(!)
column10: and the pseudo-literate's favorite word of all: ""juxtaposition."" Each of those words costs as much time to understand as a whole chapter of Erik Barnouw's book (which is succinct
column11: informative and even humorous). Mr. Nichols should be sealed in a cave and his books slung into outer space
column12: for they pollute the body of film knowledge. Don't buy ""Representing Reality"" unless you want to know how confused Mr. Nichols's reality is."

column4: and there are several moments that are just so beautiful that I just get chills listening to them. Every lyric and harmony has been precisely placed
column5: and the music always fits the idea of the song very naturally. There are some amazing performance moments on this album; Brown is an incredible pianist and singer in addition to his composing and arranging talents.This is probably the album that I listen to more than any other
column6: and I would recommend it to anyone. It is packed with amazing musicality.Don't listen to this while trying to get work done; these songs will steal your attention and keep it for the whole duration of the CD."

2923.5."Your Signature Life by Dianna Booher Personal accountability
column2: integrity
column3: character - whatever you label it
column4: it's doing the right thing
column5: even when no one else is watching. ""Your Signature Life"" is a personal-development home run!Through captivating imagery and intriguing statistics
column6: Dianna Booher challenges us to examine our lives to see what kind of character we are developing. Do we reflect light or darkness? She shows us how our experiences and relationships may help to form the way we look at the world
column7: but they do not have to define who we are or who we will become.Although we cannot control the actions of those around us
column8: we are called to control our responses to those actions. Personal accountability is not a thing of the past. We can and must have it today if we ever hope to look back over our lives and smile. Others are watching. God is watching.Ms. Booher's latest release
column9: ""Your Signature Life
column10: is a triumph for those seeking to live a life of integrity and total fulfillment."

column1: 2929.2."Wonderful book
column2: except for the part with all the words. The first time I tried to read Foundation
column3: I was six years old
column4: and it was simply too complex for my developing mind. Just a few months ago
column5: however
column6: I was cleaning out my attic and came across the same old book. To ascertain it's actual nature as interpreted by the adult mind
column7: I read it again. I was amazed not only by the sheer brillance and ingenuity of the ideas contained within it
column8: not only by the grandiose size of the subject matter
column9: but mostly by the writing
column10: which I regarded as absolutely horrid. The plot is clunky
column11: the conversations roll off the tongue like sandpaper covered in peanut butter
column12: and the descriptions could have been written better by some obscure species of mosquito. As a book
column13: it could be improved by changing the title from ""Foundation"" to ""How Not to Write a Book"" or ""Please Steal These Ideas and Rewrite Them in English."" I highly reccomend it to people for use as a very expensive and ineffective paperweight."

column1: 2930.3."Foundation The main reason I read sci-fi is to visualize strange new worlds and places. Although a good book
column2: I didn't really get a good mental picture of the different worlds involved in it except Trantor in the very beginning of the book. It was mostly about people and politics with very little of the landscapes they lived in. I guess that is why I liked the Dune and Hyperion series so much."

column1: 2931.2."Disappointing I have heard so much about this book over the years but didn't like Asimov's writing so I never read it. Well
column2: I thought maybe this was different but no
column3: it's the same poor writing. I love the idea of psychohistory but that's where the love ends for this book. And Hari Seldon dies before we get to know and like him. Dull
column4: mostly pointless conversations between people you don't know as the story jumps quickly over time ruin this book. And how lazy of Asimov to not develop his ideas. At one point he gets out of this by having a character watch a movie that we can't see which describes something that would have been interesting and clever had it been developed.I guess I'll finish the series because I've heard the other books are better. Phew
column5: glad I got this out of the way."

column2: Sporadically very Engaging Parts of the book I really enjoyed. I appreciate the twists played by characters on one another. I felt that after reading through the entire bit
column3: though
column4: that not enough had actually taken place. I didn't feel I walked away with a story I could remember. I did read in one review that this was ""serious science fiction

column6: I still give it five stars. I only would have liked that the pace be quicker.I really really enjoyedThe Hitch Hiker's Guide to the Galaxy. I would recommend that over this book Foundation

column1: 2933.4."Classic mind-stretching sci-fi This is certainly an excellent ""first"" book in the Asimov series. Even if one has not read

column1: 2934.4."The first written
column2: and the worst of the series I started reading this series with the original ""Foundation"" and was very disappointed with it. After all the acclaim it received
column3: I was expecting something truly exceptional. Instead
column4: I got a historical narrative that is closer in style to something you would read in the Brittanica for a school assignment. It is really a kind of ""mutant"" between a novel and a documentary. What's more
column5: it is exceptionally boring. What kept me going was the Asimov name on the cover and the hope of better things to come. This is not to say that it is a really bad book. I must confess that it has some interesting parts and of course
column6: the series as a whole is an absolute classic. Every other novel in the Foundation series is so brilliant
column7: that they cover for this disappointment. It must also be remembered that Asimov wrote this book in the early 50's when he was still a young and inexperienced writer"

column1: 2935.3."Romans in Space I like Foundation because it's a solid piece of sci-fi from olden days. (George Lucas's stealing of Asimov's city-planet for his Coruscant - tsk tsk
column2: Georgie - amazed me most.) Foundation does have peculiarities. People hundreds of thousands of years in the future speak like us. They use phrases like us. They also have the same atomic technology as people did in the 1950s. Asimov got a bit lazy here; he could've imagined something cooler than nukes. The galaxy is a metaphor for a crumbling Roman empire. Perhaps Terminus is Ireland. As for A's style
column3: I found his use of long adverbs rather funny. In sum
column4: a good book if you can ignore this stuff."

column1: 2936.4."Still good science fiction
column2: even for 1951 Foundation is great science fiction for the scientific minded
column3: no deus ex machina here. The only fault I find with this 1st book is that the 3 main characters are exactly the same person. Seldon
column4: Salvor Hardin and Hober Mallow are the exact same character. All calm
column5: cool and collected. Perfectly confident and perfectly logical. No difference in dialogue and problem solving skills
column6: you wouldn't be able to tell from Asimov's writing that these characters are from different time periods and are from different cultures. For that matter
column7: every character in the book seems to be of the same culture and dialect. I realize Asimov uses a minimalist style of writing
column8: like Hemmingway
column9: there are good and bad sides to this. No fleshing out of characters has to be considered weakness in Asimov's writing. It may have made for a longer book
column10: but his characters would have been better served if they all didn't behave as robots."

column6: cap in hand asking for a new book.Foundation : The Psychohistorians - Isaac AsimovFoundation : The Encyclopedists - Isaac AsimovFoundation : The Mayors - Isaac AsimovFoundation : The Traders - Isaac AsimovFoundation : The Merchant Princes - Isaac AsimovFuture prediction equations suggest Galactic Empire go bye-bye.4.5 out of 5Struggles with Seldon's legacy.3 out of 5City split and the odd ship.3.5 out of 5Commercial leading edge.3 out of 5Seldon crisis and sellers of heaps of stuff.3.5 out of 5"

column1: 2941.4."Good? You bet. Great? Not sure ... I found the politics of this novel interesting enough to disregard the dated scientific references. Seldon and his science was fascinating to behold
column2: and the plot was masterful. What concerned me was (dare I say it?) the fairly amateurish use of dialogue tags and the fact that each character seemed pretty much to speak with the same voice. Asimov wrote this as one of those authors who are at pains not to repeat 'he said'. So it must be a new tag each time
column3: no matter how ridiculous
column4: often paired with an adverb that makes you cringe: ('spluttered angrily'
column5: 'cried sternly'
column6: 'mumbled grumpily'
column7: so on.) Sad this very basic trick of writing lets down passages of vivid description and intriguing plot.Also
column8: some things seemed implausible to me
column9: such as: how was the foundation
column10: which exported its technology across the galaxy
column11: able to keep its technology secret?Nonetheless
column12: this is a series every sci-fi fan has to read - its attributes outweigh its faults by a fair margin."

column1: 2942.2."Bor-ring! I couldn't wait to read the first of the Foundation novels
column2: having got such great reviews
column3: and having heard that it's been such an inspiration to so many other sci-fi authors. But I could barely finish it. The book is flat-out boring. There is no action
column4: choosing rather to focus mostly on matters of political intrigue. If you like watching CSPAN
column5: then you'll love this book.There is also no continuity of storyline or characters. The book constantly jumps ahead in time right about the time you've wrapped your head around the current characters and plot.It's like a set of boring short stories

column1: 2951.3."Be Careful of the Edition Isaac Asimov was one of the greatest science fiction minds of the twentieth century. He was NOT

column4: the first novel in the ever-lengthening Foundation series
column5: is a collection of short stories originally published in ""Astounding"" magazine. The first couple are very good
column6: but the last few are pretty uninteresting. The writing is uneven
column7: dialogue is unrealistic
column8: and characters are wooden and one-dimensional. And yet
column9: through Asimov's wonderfully creative idea of psychohistory and its use in saving a dying Galactic Empire
column10: this series became one of the best science fiction stories of all time
column11: and well worth reading.Do be careful which edition you read. I read the Del Ray paperback edition

column2: it's Asimov This book has all the Asimovian trademarks: intriguing ideas marred by utterly forgettable and indeed interchangeable characters
column3: cringe-inducing dialogue
column4: and a plodding storytelling style and pace. Later in his career Asimov fixed these problems *somewhat*
column5: but at this point he was very young and they are present in full force. The unfortunate truth is that this book simply doesn't deserve the praise heaped upon it; it's some kind of herd mentality that leads to so many people venerating Foundation. If you are seriously into science fiction
column6: then by all means read the entire Foundation series: it has historical importance and there is enjoyment to be had there. But I hate to think that there are people who are introduced to science fiction by this book."

column1: 2964.3."A classic ... good thing it's short. Let's face it: Isaac Asimov was not a very good writer

column3: 'Foundation' is a must-read.The importance of 'Foundation' in the genre may force us to allow for the blandness of its prose; however
column4: it does not excuse it. The characters are ciphers
column5: the style is blunt and ugly
column6: like a sledgehammer
